content: This is a postgraduate course that provides an introduction to quantitative methods in use in modern environmental and resource economics. Emphasis is on causal inference and regression-based methods, including key empirical designs (e.g. fixed effects, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity, difference-in-differences etc.). We also cover additional topics of interest, such as machine learning. Students learn how to apply these methods in R.
summary: This is a postgraduate course that provides an introduction to quantitative methods in use in modern environmental and resource economics. title: GY428: Applied Quantitative Methods

summary: This is a postgraduate course that covers the economics, markets, regulations and policies that shape the energy sector and the clean energy transition. Content includes topics such as: energy fundamentals; supply, demand and prices; utility regulation; consumers and retail energy markets; energy efficiency; environmental externalities; energy and development. The course also includes an electricity market strategy game.
title: GY478: Energy Markets and the Clean Energy Transition

content: This is a postgraduate course that covers the use of applied economics in the context of project appraisal and policy evaluation. My teaching on this course focuses on topics related to related to cost-benefit analysis and environmental valuation; stated and revealed preferences methods; and the use of program evaluation in policymaking. I also host a panel discussion with experts from industry, consulting and government.

title: GY455: Economic Appraisal and Valuation

content: This course is an undergraduate level introduction to economic principles in the analysis of environmental change and natural resource use. My teaching on this course focuses on topics related to cost-benefit analysis and environmental valuation; stated and revealed preferences methods; sustainable development; biodiversity; and energy markets.
